user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
- test_code: a modified not_found_page code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/583.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If the MISRA C rule is not violated, you can just return an empty string for the test code.
Here are the constraints for the test code:
- DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
- The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
- The test code MUST include line breaks.
- The test code MUST preserve the original logic of not_found_page as much as possible.
- You MUST NOT define the main function.
- You MUST NOT define macros.
- The test code MUST not contain any mock functions.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of not_found_page:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
not_found_page (const void *cls,
                const char *mime,
                struct Session *session,
                struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  struct MHD_Response *response;
  (void) cls;     /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) session; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  /* unsupported HTTP method */
  response =
    MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (strlen (NOT_FOUND_ERROR),
                                            (const void *) NOT_FOUND_ERROR);
  if (NULL == response)
    return MHD_NO;
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection,
                            MHD_HTTP_NOT_FOUND,
                            response);
  if (MHD_YES !=
      MHD_add_response_header (response,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_ENCODING,
                               mime))
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to set content encoding header!\n");
  }
  MHD_destroy_response (response);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function not_found_page:
#define NOT_FOUND_ERROR "<html><head><title>Not found</title></head><body>Go away.</body></html>"
...
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (size_t size,
                                        const void *buffer)
{
  return MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls (size,
                                                                 buffer,
                                                                 NULL,
                                                                 NULL);
}
</additional code>
Judge whether the above not_found_page code violates the rule 21.17 or not.
scenario: The function not_found_page calls strlen on the macro NOT_FOUND_ERROR, which is a string literal. Using strlen on a valid null-terminated string literal is safe and does not access out of bounds. Subsequently, the string literal pointer is passed to MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static, which presumably treats it correctly. There is no evidence that string handling functions access beyond the bounds of objects referenced by their pointers. Therefore, no violation of Rule 21.17 occurs.
